hints.Empirical Process Control: Scrum is based on transparency, inspection, and adaptation, allowing teams to make data-driven decisions and adapt to change.
hints.Self-Organizing Teams: Scrum teams are encouraged to self-organize and make decisions collectively, without relying on a top-down management approach.
hints.Collaboration: Scrum emphasizes close collaboration between the team members and stakeholders, enabling effective communication and shared understanding.
hints.Cross-Functional Teams: Scrum teams are composed of members with diverse skill sets, which enables them to handle all aspects of the project without depending on external resources.
hints.Timeboxing: All Scrum events, such as Sprints, Daily Stand-ups, Sprint Planning, Sprint Review, and Sprint Retrospective, have a predefined duration, ensuring efficient time management.
hints.Iterative Development: Scrum focuses on delivering small, incremental improvements, allowing teams to learn and adapt as they progress through the project.
hints.Continuous Improvement: Scrum teams continuously inspect and adapt their processes, aiming to improve their performance and product quality.
hints.Prioritization: Scrum emphasizes prioritizing work based on business value, ensuring that the most valuable features are developed and delivered first.
hints.Incremental Delivery: Scrum promotes delivering working, usable increments of the product at the end of each Sprint, ensuring a continuous flow of value to the stakeholders.
hints.User Involvement: Scrum emphasizes the involvement of end-users and stakeholders throughout the development process, ensuring that their needs and feedback are taken into account.
hints.Flexibility: Scrum allows for changing requirements and priorities, enabling teams to adapt to new information and evolving business needs.
hints.Sustainable Pace: Scrum encourages maintaining a sustainable work pace, ensuring that the team can consistently deliver high-quality work without burnout.
hints.Focus: Scrum promotes concentrating on a limited set of tasks within each Sprint, ensuring that the team remains focused and committed to delivering the agreed-upon objectives.
hints.Transparency: Scrum relies on transparency in decision-making, progress tracking, and information sharing, enabling effective communication and trust-building.
hints.Inspect and Adapt: Scrum teams regularly inspect their work and processes, adapting to improve efficiency and effectiveness based on feedback and lessons learned.
hints.Definition of Done: Scrum teams establish a shared understanding of what it means for work to be completed, ensuring consistency and quality across the project.
hints.Respect: Scrum promotes a culture of respect, valuing each team member's unique skills, experiences, and perspectives.
hints.Courage: Scrum encourages team members to be courageous in making decisions, embracing change, and addressing challenges.
hints.Commitment: Scrum teams commit to achieving the Sprint goals and continuously improving their performance.
hints.Visibility: Scrum artifacts, such as the Product Backlog, Sprint Backlog, and Increment, provide visibility into the team's progress and help manage expectations.
